subject: Dual-boot: BIOS attribute for choosing OS

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build Successful 

https://openpower.xyz/job/openbmc-repository-ci/46100/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 1:

There is another design someone is from Yadro is working on that allows extended information for the boot source.  It seems their intended usage of it is to allow expressing UUIDs of HD/SSDs as the target boot device.  I think there is some alignment with what Yadro is attempting to do and what you'd like to do here.

I left some comments here and I think what I'm proposing here would work for this purpose as well:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/28175/1/designs/boot_mailbox.md#70

Patch Set 2: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build Successful 

https://openpower.xyz/job/openbmc-repository-ci/46529/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 2:

Is there also going to be a way to know what mode the system was actually booted in?  Or will something enforce that this can't be set after a boot?

Patch Set 2:

> Is there also going to be a way to know what mode the system was
 > actually booted in?  Or will something enforce that this can't be
 > set after a boot?

Hostboot can change the PLDM BIOS attribute if they're rejecting the BMC request to choose a certain hyp, and that can cause this D-Bus property to change. Does that answer your question? Or do you have some other concern?

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Is there also going to be a way to know what mode the system was
>  > actually booted in?  Or will something enforce that this can't be
>  > set after a boot?
> 
> Hostboot can change the PLDM BIOS attribute if they're rejecting the BMC request to choose a certain hyp, and that can cause this D-Bus property to change. Does that answer your question? Or do you have some other concern?

I think so.  For my situation, I think I may need to know if its OPAL or PHYP when the OsStatus  property changes to say the host is running.  It sounds then like I can just read this property, and not have to worry about it not being accurate (like from someone setting it to take affect on the next boot already).

Patch Set 2:

> > Patch Set 2:
 > >
 > > > Is there also going to be a way to know what mode the system
 > was
 > >  > actually booted in?  Or will something enforce that this can't
 > be
 > >  > set after a boot?
 > >
 > > Hostboot can change the PLDM BIOS attribute if they're rejecting
 > the BMC request to choose a certain hyp, and that can cause this
 > D-Bus property to change. Does that answer your question? Or do you
 > have some other concern?
 > 
 > I think so.  For my situation, I think I may need to know if its
 > OPAL or PHYP when the OsStatus  property changes to say the host is
 > It sounds then like I can just read this property, and
 > not have to worry about it not being accurate (like from someone
 > setting it to take affect on the next boot already).

No, you can't. For the same reason you stated. Since this reflects a user setting, it is possible that a user change the setting at any point of time. The host firmware will come and read it only the next time.

What you're looking for has to be a different object/property on D-Bus, and is not the purpose of this one.

 > What you're looking for has to be a different object/property on

@Pavithra - I think you should improve the documentation to make the above evident.

Is there a story about showing the actual boot target?

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> There is another design someone is from Yadro is working on that allows extended information for the boot source.  It seems their intended usage of it is to allow expressing UUIDs of HD/SSDs as the target boot device.  I think there is some alignment with what Yadro is attempting to do and what you'd like to do here.
> 
> I left some comments here and I think what I'm proposing here would work for this purpose as well:
> 
> https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/28175/1/designs/boot_mailbox.md#70

Hi Patrick

From the other review:

> Can we simply add a free-form string or array[uint8] field into Control.Boot.Source called "ExtendedBootSource" or something like that?

Is your suggestion more or less that we move this to the xyz namespace and call it ExtendedBootSource instead of Source?

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > There is another design someone is from Yadro is working on that allows extended information for the boot source.  It seems their intended usage of it is to allow expressing UUIDs of HD/SSDs as the target boot device.  I think there is some alignment with what Yadro is attempting to do and what you'd like to do here.
> > 
> > I left some comments here and I think what I'm proposing here would work for this purpose as well:
> > 
> > https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/28175/1/designs/boot_mailbox.md#70
> 
> Hi Patrick
> 
> From the other review:
> 
> > Can we simply add a free-form string or array[uint8] field into Control.Boot.Source called "ExtendedBootSource" or something like that?
> 
> Is your suggestion more or less that we move this to the xyz namespace and call it ExtendedBootSource instead of Source?

Yes.  It seems like these two designs are concerning a similar issue and so I'd prefer if we can converge on something that works for both concerns.

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 5:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 1:
> > > 
> > > There is another design someone is from Yadro is working on that allows extended information for the boot source.  It seems their intended usage of it is to allow expressing UUIDs of HD/SSDs as the target boot device.  I think there is some alignment with what Yadro is attempting to do and what you'd like to do here.
> > > 
> > > I left some comments here and I think what I'm proposing here would work for this purpose as well:
> > > 
> > > https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/28175/1/designs/boot_mailbox.md#70
> > 
> > Hi Patrick
> > 
> > From the other review:
> > 
> > > Can we simply add a free-form string or array[uint8] field into Control.Boot.Source called "ExtendedBootSource" or something like that?
> > 
> > Is your suggestion more or less that we move this to the xyz namespace and call it ExtendedBootSource instead of Source?
> 
> Yes.  It seems like these two designs are concerning a similar issue and so I'd prefer if we can converge on something that works for both concerns.

Having said that, I think having the enumerations here is reasonable.  We can use the enumerations to come up with well-defined ExtendedBootSource property values (ex. com.ibm.Host.Source.OPAL).

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I don't think we need this, because this is basically a BIOS attribute. The BMC wouldn't need new D-Bus interfaces for BIOS attributes, once we have the following : https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/#/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/18242/

Removed reviewer Tom Joseph with the following votes:

* Code-Review+1 by Tom Joseph <tomjoseph@in.ibm.com>
This D-Bus interface isn't specific to PLDM. You need to rephrase this.

Even if we go with the proposal I made, I think that having these enumerations defined like this is probably a good idea.  That way we create enumerations like 'com.ibm.Host.Source.PowerVM' as values we could fill into the ExtendedBootSource property I mentioned.
I want you to add this to the Description in the yaml file as well.
Seems like we should have a default?
